Introduction

Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic skin condition characterized by recurrent inflammatory nodules and abscesses that leads to sinus tract formation and scarring.  It primarily affects folliculopilosebaceous units in intertriginous areas (eg, axillae, groin, perianal region).  HS can significantly impact a patient's quality of life due to its physical, emotional, and social consequences.

Pathophysiology



HS begins with the occlusion of folliculopilosebaceous units* caused by keratinocyte hyperproliferation and abnormal keratinocyte differentiation (

figure 1
).  Mechanical stress (eg, friction in intertriginous areas) then leads to follicular rupture and the release of proinflammatory contents.  Exacerbated by immune dysregulation and subsequent bacterial colonization or infection, the initial inflammation evolves into a chronic inflammatory response that progresses to abscesses, sinus tracts (formed by epithelial stem cells released from follicular rupture), comedones (from follicular destruction), and extensive fibrosis.



*Previously, apocrine sweat glands were thought to play a major role in HS; however, it is now believed that folliculopilosebaceous units are at the center of pathogenesis.

Risk factors



  • Smoking:  There is a strong association between HS and tobacco use.  Nicotine and other tobacco components are thought to stimulate follicular occlusion through their effect on keratinocytes.  In addition, these substances have proinflammatory effects on neutrophils and T lymphocytes and promote the production of tumor necrosis factor-alpha by keratinocytes.
  • Family history:  Genetic susceptibility is a significant risk factor, with some cases inherited in an autosomal dominant-like pattern.
  • Hormonal factors:  The rarity of HS in prepubertal children, improvement of HS with antiandrogen therapy in women, perimenstrual flares, and improvement in pregnancy suggest hormonal factors in HS.  (For this reason, antiandrogen therapy is sometimes used in management.)
  • Obesity:  Obesity creates a hyperandrogenic, proinflammatory, and insulin-resistant state,  which promotes follicular plugging and continuous inflammation.  (For this reason, metformin is sometimes used in management.)  Obesity-related increased friction in intertriginous areas also facilitates the development of HS.

Pathology



Histologic examination of HS lesions reveals follicular plugging, follicular hyperkeratosis (excess keratin formation), follicular epithelial hyperplasia, epidermal hyperplasia, and perifollicular inflammatory infiltrate.  Collections of pus-filled cavities (abscesses) and fibrous tissue (scarring) may also be present in more advanced disease.

Clinical presentation



HS begins as a solitary, painful, inflamed nodule that can last for several days to months before progressing to an abscess with purulent or serosanguineous drainage (

image 1
).  The symptoms typically improve after drainage, but as the disease progresses, multiple nodules develop and undergo a similar cycle of abscess formation and drainage.  Chronic inflammation ultimately leads to sinus tract formation, comedones (indicative of follicular destruction) (
image 2
), and significant scarring.



Lesions typically occur in intertriginous areas (eg, axilla, inguinal area), although other areas may also be affected (eg, scalp, nape, trunk).

Diagnosis



The diagnosis is made clinically based on a history of recurrent inflammatory nodules, abscesses, and scarring, especially when these lesions occur in intertriginous areas.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis can vary based on the location of HS lesions.



  • Carbuncle/furuncle (
    image 3
    ):  are abscesses surrounding hair follicles.  They usually resolve completely with drainage and/or antibacterial therapy, but HS typically persists or recurs despite these measures.  Unlike HS, sinus tracts, comedones, and scarring are not features of carbuncle/furuncle.
  • Acne vulgaris (
    image 4
    ):  presents with comedones, red papules, pustules, and sometimes painful nodules, typically on the face of adolescents; in contrast, HS usually does not affect the face.  Acne may also affect the trunk, but unlike HS, acne tends to have a diffuse distribution that spares the intertriginous areas.
  • Genital herpes infection (
    image 5
    ):  causes recurrent painful vesicles that break to form ulcers on the anogenital region; painful nodules with seropurulent drainage (as seen in HS) are not present.
  • Granuloma inguinale:  is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis that typically presents with a painless red nodule that then ulcerates.  Unlike HS, the lesion is painless and readily bleeds when touched.
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):  is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3.  Patients can have painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (ie, buboes) that can cause scarring and strictures within the inguinal region.  However, LGV does not cause recurrent infection, unlike HS.
  • Lichen sclerosus:  classically presents with white, cigarette paperâ€“like skin due to epidermal and dermal atrophy, giving it a scarred appearance.  It can affect the vulva/vaginal introitus, penis/urethra, and trunk/extremities.  However, unlike HS, lichen sclerosus does not present with nodules, abscesses, comedones, and sinus tracts.
  • Pilonidal disease (
    image 6
    ):  presents with a pit in the superior intergluteal region (pilonidal sinus tract) and recurrent pilonidal abscesses.  It is distinguished from HS by its location and solitary presentation.
  • Hyperhidrosis:  is a disorder primarily involving eccrine sweat glands and presents with excessive sweating and associated skin maceration (eg, in the axilla).  Excessive sweating is not a feature of HS.

Management



General measures include maintaining a healthy weight, smoking cessation, and pain management (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs).  Pharmacologic intervention and surgical management depend on disease severity and acuity.

Therapy for chronic lesions



Pharmacologic therapy takes weeks to months to work.  Reevaluation after 3 months is advised after therapy initiation.



  • Inflammatory lesions only (mild disease)
    • First-line therapy:  typically clindamycin (efficacy sometimes may be limited and oral tetracycline therapy may be necessary)
    • Adjunctive therapy:
      • Antiandrogenic therapy (eg, oral contraceptive pills, spironolactone) for women with premenstrual exacerbations and polycystic ovary syndrome
      • Metformin for patients with obesity (to enhance insulin sensitivity and downregulate insulin-like growth factor, which may promote HS)
  • Inflammatory lesions with skin tunnels or scarring (moderate/severe disease)
    • First-line therapy: oral tetracycline (eg, doxycycline), with or without metformin and antiandrogenic therapy
    • Second-line therapy: adalimumab (tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitor) or alternatives (eg, secukinumab, infliximab, acitretin)
    • Third-line therapy: wide excision (although it offers the best chance for resolution of HS, it carries significant risks, including long recovery times and additional scarring); unroofing of skin tunnels

Therapy for acute lesions



Acute flares (eg, acute painful nodules/abscesses) may require the following measures to achieve immediate pain relief.



  • Warm compresses
  • Intralesional corticosteroid injection
  • Punch debridement (partial unroofing of an abscess with a 5- to 8-mm punch tool), followed by healing by secondary intention
  • Topical resorcinol (which has anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and keratolytic properties).
  • Systemic corticosteroid therapy (only for severe cases)


Incision and drainage is generally not advised because they promote lesion recurrence.  In contrast, a punch debridement or unroofing procedure carries a much lower risk for recurrence.

Complications



  • Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC):  Chronic HS can lead to the development of cutaneous SCC, especially in the perianal region.  An enlarging ulcer or a rapidly growing lesion warrants biopsy to rule out malignancy.
  • Depression/suicide:  HS increases the risk for depression and suicide due to the profound psychologic and social impact of the disease.
  • Lymphedema:  Scarring associated with HS in the axilla and groin can interfere with lymphatic drainage, causing lymphedema of the arms, legs, and genitalia.
  • Restricted movement:  Scarring, especially in the axillae and thighs, can lead to restricted and painful movement.

Prognosis



HS is a chronic, recurring condition without a cure.  The prognosis of HS depends on the severity of the disease at diagnosis.  When diagnosed early (eg, nodules or abscesses without scarring or sinus tracts), HS can be effectively managed.  However, once sinus tracts and/or scarring has developed, the disease becomes more difficult to manage, often requiring a multidisciplinary approach.

Summary



Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) (

) is a chronic skin condition caused by the occlusion, rupture, and inflammation of folliculopilosebaceous units.  It typically affects the intertriginous areas (eg, axilla, groin) and presents with recurrent inflammatory nodules and abscesses that eventually result in sinus tract formation and scarring.  Treatment typically involves chronic oral antibiotic therapy (eg, doxycycline) with or without metformin and antiandrogen therapy (for women); for severe, recalcitrant cases, biologic therapy (eg, adalimumab) and surgical wide excision may be necessary.  HS can lead to multiple complications (eg, cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, suicide, lymphedema, chronic pain); early diagnosis before progression to scarring and sinus tract formation typically leads to better outcomes.
